Key Arguments: The legislation infringes on the right to freedom of opinion and expression as outlined in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), to which Australia is a signatory.
Censorship is an unfair form of control and is unnecessary in a just government.
Government censorship can lead to a totalitarian state by limiting what can be aired and written.
Censorship could be used to hide government actions and initiatives that work against the people.
Transparency is essential, and the media should be free to present information, even if it embarrasses the government.
Notable Quotes: A just government allows the people to be free in their actions and deeds; censorship is an unfair form of control that is not necessary.
When the government censors the media, they are stifling freedom of speech, and that can lead eventually to somewhat of a totalitarian state.
Transparency is far too vital an aspect of government to ignore simply because it is inconvenient.
